stem: A 52-year-old client with chest pain is being evaluated. Based on the documentation in the 12-Lead EKG & Hemodynamic Stability Log, which intervention is the highest priority?

tabs.title: 12-Lead EKG Report
tabs.content:
Impression: ST-segment elevation in Leads II, III, and aVF.
Localization: Acute **Inferior** Myocardial Infarction.
Comment: Right-sided V4R lead also shows ST-elevation, suggesting Right Ventricular (RV) involvement.

tabs.title: Hemodynamic Trends
tabs.content:
IndicatorResultStatus
Blood Pressure78/42Hypotensive
Heart Rate110Tachycardic
Breath SoundsClear in all fieldsNormal
Neck VeinsDistended (JVD)High Right-Heart Pressure

tabs.title: Standing Cardiac Orders
tabs.content:
1. Morphine 2mg IV for pain.
2. Nitroglycerin 0.4mg SL every 5 mins.
3. Normal Saline - keep vein open at 25 mL/hr.

options.text: Initiate aggressive IV fluid boluses with Normal Saline
Apply a CPAP machine for impending pulmonary edema

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing an **Inferior MI with Right Ventricular (RV) involvement (a1)**. In an RV MI, the right side of the heart is weak and fails to push blood into the lungs. This causes blood to back up into the body (**JVD**) but leaves the **lungs clear**. Unlike a left-sided MI, the RV is **preload-dependent**. The most critical action is to **administer IV fluids (a1)** to 'force' blood into the lungs. **Nitroglycerin (a2) and Morphine (a3)** are strictly **contraindicated** because they decrease preload, which would cause the blood pressure to vanish and lead to cardiac arrest.
clinicalPearls: Inferior MI = Leads II, III, aVF.
RV MI Triad: Hypotension, JVD, and Clear Lungs.
Treatment Rule: Fluids are the FIX. Nitro is the KILLER.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing Nitroglycerin (a2) because the client has 'Chest Pain.'
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always check the **EKG Localization**. If you see II, III, aVF (Inferior), check the BP. If BP is low and JVD is present, Nitro is your enemy. Fluids are your only friend.

mnemonic.title: Inferior-Preload
mnemonic.expansion: Bottom of the heart (Inferior). Needs lots of water (Preload). Avoid the Nitro (Vasodilator).
